word.definition: The sort of environment in which an organism normally lives and grows.
The living organisms in a particular place, together with their physical environment.
All of the groups of animals or plants living together in a environment interacting with one another.
Organisms that obtain nutrients by consuming decomposing plant and animal parts as well as organic fecal matter.
(An) organism(s) that decomposes organic material.
The first level in a food pyramid; consist of organisms that generate the food used by all other organisms. Includes plants (photosynthesis).
An animal that feeds primarily on plants.
Animals that are adapted to eat plants.
A energy level whithin an ecosystem that consists of organisms that share the same function in the food chain.
The process of eliminating or expelling waste matter.
The metabolic processes allowing organisms to obtain energy from organic molecules.
A 'chain' of organisms which are dependant on the previous member as a food source.
An animal which feed primarily on other aminals.
The rate at which the procducers of an ecosystem capture and store energy as biomass.
Net primary producticity is gross primary productivity less the amount of energy lost in respiration. It is the energy passed to the next trophic level.
The rate of generation of biomass in an ecosystem by the primary consumers (herbivores).
The weight of dried organisms (water removed) in a given area.
The process by which a community gives way to another.
A stable community formed as a result of sucessful adaptation to the environment.
Measurement based on numbers as opposed to a quality.
The conditions and surroundings which an organisms inhabits.
The carrier of genetic information in (most) organisms. Abbreviation of Deoxyribonucleic acid.
The strand of DNA which is used to determine the sequence of nucleotides in RNA after transcription.
Twisted and compact structire of DNA and protein which carries genes.
A distinct sequence of nucleotides forming part of a chromosome which dictates which polypeptide should be synthesised in protein synthesis.
Process in which cells build proteins at ribosomes using tRNA and mRNA with ammino acids.
The process in which DNA is transcribed into an mRNA molecule for protein synthesis.
Performed at the ribosomes translation takes nucleotide triplets on mRNA and builds a sequnce of amino acids as part of protein synthesis.
Abbreviation of Ribonucleic acid. Carries instrictions from DNA in most organisms by can be the carrier of genetic information (instead of DNA) in some viruses.
Sequence of three nucleotides which together indicate an amino acid which should be built into a polypeptide chain.

Messenger RNA is a template for protein synthesis. It is made from transcription before mRNA leaves the nucleus through nuclear pores and travels to ribosome(s) where it is read to synthesis proteins.
Transfer RNA is a small RNA molecule that joins an amino acid to a polypeptide chain as part of protein synthesis.
Cell division which produces four haploid daughter cells.
Chromosomes which have the same structural features and gene loci which pair up during meiosis.
A cell organelle found in the cytoplasm consisting of a large and small sub unit which reads mRNA and produces polypeptide chains.
The alleles at the same loci of each chromosome of an organism.
The observable characteristics of an individual produced by its genes.
Occuring during meiosis it is the exchange of genes between homologous chromosomes.
The random manner in which chromosomes are distributed to each gamete produced in meiosis.
The mature female reproductive cell.
The female reproductive orgam in females in which ova (eggs) are produced.
An animal organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation.
A male of female mature germ cell which when meeting with each other form a zygote.
The production and subsequent development of mature spermatozoa.
The production and subsequent development of an ovum.
Having two sets of chromosomes, one maternal and one paternal.
Having a single set of chromosomes.
The cell formeed from spermatogonium in the seconda stage of spermatozoa formation. Spermatocytes later divide into spermatids through meiosis.
The name given to the immature female reproductive cell before it is fertilized.
The acrosome is an organelle that develops over the anterior half of the head in the spermatozoa (sperm cells) it contains enzymes which break down the outer membrane of the ovum.
A hollow structure in early embryonic development that contains a cluster of cells which give rise to the embryo.
Cells forming the outer layer of a blastocyst which provide nutrients to the developing embryo and eventually form the placenta.
A membrane that surrounds and protects an embryo.
The outermost membrane surrounding an embryo.
Abbreviation for human chorionic gonadotropin. hCG is a hormome produced in pregnancy which acts to maintain the corpus luteum.
Literally 'yellow body' the corpus luteum develops from the ovarian follicle and produces progesterone. This is the hormone which thickens the uterus lining for implantation.
Highly specific antibodies which are clones of a single parent cell.
The part of the plant that contains the reproductive organs which is often surrounded with petals.
A segment of the corolla of the flower.
Part of the female reproductive organs of a flower that receive the pollen.
The part of the stamen that contains the pollen.
The male reproductive organ of a flower. Consists of anther and filament.
Forms a protective layer around the bud but becomes leaf like strutures at the base of the flower.
An elongated extension of the ovary which supports the stigma.
The part of the ovary (seed plants) that contains the female germ cell. Later becomes the seed.
A cell within the ovule where fertilisation occurs. Contains the endosperm nucleus and (fertilised ovum) the developing embryo.
Large area at the end of the stem which the flower is inserted into.
A group of flowers that have flowers and produced seeds (in a carpel).
The depositing of pollen on the stigma so that fertilisation can occur.
Have the moisture removed.
The nuclues of the pollen grain which divides to form the sperm nuclei.
A cell in the male gametophyte in plants that grows into the ovule.
The 'bursting' open of a seed vessel.
Produced by the fusion of one male gamete with two polar bodies which forms the endosperm which provides nutrition (in the form of starch) to the embryo.
Tough outer protective layers.
A flowering plant whose embryo produces two seed leaves (cotyledons)
A flowering plant whose embryo produces one seed leaf (cotyledon)
The process of growing/shoot formation that occurs after a period of dormancy in plants.
Plural of apex, the top of something.
An enzyme which converts starch as well as glycogen into monosaccharides (simple sugars).
The young shoot or stem of a plant embryo.
The young (primary) root of a plant embryo.

keywords.topic: Effects of human activity on the environment

word.definition: A water soluable anticoagulent that is used as a rat poison.
The ability to not be adversly affected by something.
A medicine wich prevents the growth of of kills microorganisms. e.g. Penicillin.
An enzyme produced by some bacteria which are resistant to antibiotics like penicillin. (Actually a form of Beta-lactamse)
Temporary fusion of bacteria to exchange genetic material.
(Selective breeding) Intentional breeding for certain traits.
To breed from a closely related group.
To breed from group which is not closely related.
To have no living members of a spcies.
A species of organisms at high risk of extinction.
the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species which aims aim is to ensure that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not threaten the survival of the species.
The protection and restoration of wildlife and/or the environment.
Tourism with the intent of supporting conservation efforts.
The cultivation of just one crop in a given area.
The clearing of areas of forests.
Allowing a damaged area to recover.
Gradual distruction.
The periodic cutting back of trees/shrubs in order to stimulate growth.
The time between crop rotations.
The cutting out of trees that are mature or defective.
A fuel produced from living material.
Fishing by dragging a large net along the bottom a body of water.
Using a large net which is kept upright by floats and weights which drifts with the tide or currents to catch fish e.g. herring.
Depleting the stock of fish in a body of water through excessive fishing.
Excessive nutrients in a body of water caused by (agricultural) run off. Often causes dense plant growth on the water e.g. algae.
The gradual increase in the temperature of our atmosphere.
A gas which contributes to the greenhouse effect through absorbtion of infrared radiation e.g. C02 & CFC's.
A substance that is added to soil to increase crop production/growth of plant life.
Salts of nitric acid which contain the NO3 group.
Salts of phosphoric acid.
Sudden growth of cyanobacteria on a body of water.
Variation which is distributed in a continuous way such as a range of heights.
Variation which can be split into distinct groups such as eye colour.
A characteristic which can be passed from parent to offspring.
A characteristic which can not be passed from parent to offspring
A blood classification system for human blood which consists of four types A, B, O & AB
Variation in the observabnle characteristics of an individual.
An agent which makes a population change genetically.
Preying on animals.
The variety of different genes in a population.
A community of animals and plants.
Variation in the occurences of different genotypes as a result of reproduction.
The tendancy of better adapted organisms to survive and produce more offspring.
The formation of distinct species through evolution.
The speciation which occurs when a population becomes sperated as a result of geographical factors such as mountains.
The speciation which occurs when a population is prevented from interbreeding.
A form of reproductuve isolation in which animals which have complex mating rituals cannot elicit the necessary response in a potential partner.
A form of reproductuve isolation in which the genetalia of two subspecies or groups is incompatible.
A form of reproductuve isolation in which the sperm fails to survive in the oviduct or pollen fails to germinate on the stigma.
Offspring of plants or animals of different species.
Failiure of the embryo to develop in hybrids as a result of chromosomes no longer matching.
The fact that hybrids are sterile as a result of the inability for the chromosomes from each parent to pair in meiosis preventing gamete production.
An organism that is produced asexually from a parent to which it is genetically identical.
The creation of identical copies of an embryo by embryo splitting.
A form of cloning in which the DNA from an oocyte (unfertilized egg) is replaced by injecting the nucleus which contains the DNA to be cloned.
A change in the coding of a gene which can be passed on to future generations.
A descendant of an organism.
An undifferentiated which can produce other types of cell through differentiation.
Lierally 'In glass' e.g. a test tube or petri dish.
Become different through growth/development.
Growing cells from living tissue in an atrificial medium.
Using the principles of tissue growth to produce functional replacement tissue for clinical use.
Relating to the embryo.
Propagation of plants through growth in tissue culture and then planting them out.
Capable of giving rise to any cell type
Plant tissue at the tip of the root and shoot which forms new tissue.
Hard formation of tissue.
Breed an organism through natural processes from parent stock.
International project to chart the entire genetic material of a human being. Completed 2000.
Fragment of DNA or RNA that is used to detect the presence of complimentary nucleotide sequences.
Before symptoms are exhibited.
Before birth.
A neurodegenerative genetic disorder that affects muscle coordination and leads to cognitive decline. It is more common in Western Europeans and is caused by dominant mutation of the Huntingtin gene.
The most common form of dementia. Loss of cognitive ability.
Chromosome that is not a sex chromosome.
An autosomal (non sex linked) recessive genetic disorder that affects the lungs and other organs causing thick, viscous secretions as a result of abnormal chloride (ion) transport.
Sphere of phospholipids which surround a water molecule.
A duct joining the pancreas to the common bile duct to supply pancreatic juices which aid in digestion.
Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator a protein ion channel which transports chloride which is also coded by the CFTR gene.
A small DNA molecule that is separate from, and replicates independently of chromosomal DNA.
A ligase that catalyzes the bonding of free ends of double-stranded DNA with a phosphodiester bond.
DNA sequences that result from the use of laboratory methods to bring together genetic material from multiple sources.
Enzymes which can cut DNA at or near a specific sequence of bases.
The ends of a DNA double helix where one strand is longer than the other.
An enzyme that catalyzes the formation of DNA from an RNA template.
An organism that contains genetic material from another organism (that has been inserted artificially).
Genetically modified/Genetically modified organism.
The movement of charged particles in a fluid or gel under the influence of an electric field.
A technique used for the separation of DNA, RNA as well as protein molecules.
An enzyme that catalyses polymer formation.
Compound consisting of two or more amino acids linked in a chain.
The genetic 'make up' of an organism.
A change in the base sequences of DNA that can be inherited by future generations.
Sections of DNA.
Alternative forms of the same gene. There are usually two for each gene.
Where both alleles are expressed in the characteristics of an orgaism.
Allele which expresses itself even when present with the recessive allele.
Allele which expresses itself only if present with another recessive allele.
Having both alleles recessive (one from the mother and one from the father).
Having both alleles domminant (one from the mother and one from the father).
Having one dominant and one recessive allele (one from the mother and one from the father).
The characteristics expressed in the organism as a result of its genotype.
A cross resulting in a hybrid which is heterozygous for a specific gene.
A cross resulting in a hybrid which is heterozygous for alleles of two different genes.
A cross involving an organism with the same genetics as a parent of that organism.
A statistical test which determines the fit between observed values and those expected.
A modification to the structure of a gene that can be passed on to later generations.
An agent which causes genetic mutation. e.g. a chemical
Hereditary form of anaemia where a mutated form of haemoglobin distorts the red blood cells into a crescent shape at low oxygen levels. (Common in Africa/those of African descent)
A gene mutation in which a substitution occurs.
The form of hemoglobin found in people with sickle cell anaemia.
The failing of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids to separate normally.
Speration of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids.
An extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy is an extra chromosome), Trisomy 21 is the most common form of Down's syndrome.
Having four homologous sets of chromosomes.
Having tetraploid cells.
Containing more than two homologous sets of chromosomes.
Substance that can cause cancer in living tissue.
A gene that can cause cancer (turn a cell into a tumour cell).
T cells which suppress the immune response of B cells and/or other T cells
